text: these are nervous times in Ukraine
these men stood on the barricades in
Kiev's Independence Square now they face
a new challenge
basic training another line of defense
in a country now under pressure from
Moscow a country that feels a little
vulnerable the Ukrainian Parliament has
now approved the partial mobilization of
the Armed Forces to ensure that they are
at full military readiness but the
government also wants to recruit 10,000
members of this new National Guard
within two weeks and the authorities are
also sending a defiant message and crane
stands ready to defend itself hence the
invitation to the media to see all this
hardly a match for the Russian army but
they want to put on a show
we must we see this danger we've seen
Russian troops near our borders we see
dangerous events in our cities and in
order to provide additional security we
decided to mobilize our people it's part
of a propaganda war but also seen here
as a reaction to a real threat and as
new recruits practice their skills the
same message is repeated Crimea was is
and will remain part of Ukraine will
train for as long as necessary and after
that we'll be ready to stand out for the
defense of our country and its borders
wherever we're needed it all helps boost
morale but events have moved fast
sometimes with bewildering speed and the
uncomfortable truth is that Ukraine's
future is not entirely in its own hands
Chris Morris BBC News Kiev
